Graphical abstract Mesoporous silica SBA-15 and ZrSBA-15 (Si/Zr = 10) were prepared and used as supports of platinum and molybdenum based catalysts to be tested in the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) reaction of dibenzofuran (DBF) as a model compound present in biomass derived bio-oil, at 3 MPa and 275 °C. It is evaluated the bifunctionality of Pt based catalysts by adding Mo to the catalyst formulation or by increasing the acidity of the material support employed. The catalysts showed significant differences in HDO activity as well as selectivity towards O-free products. The incorporation of Mo positively affected the DBF conversion and selectivity, obtaining better results than monometallic catalysts. In contrast, the presence of Zr in the support sharply decreased the conversion of the monometallic Pt sample and also of the bimetallic PtMo one, although in a lesser extent. Considering characterization results, the activity was explained in terms of acidity, reducibility, surface metal exposure and interaction between the phases present. PtMo/SBA-15 sample presented better catalytic results due to an intermediate acidity, better reducibility and greater Pt + Mo surface exposure. Moreover, the presence of Mo decreases the amount of carbon on the surface, improving the catalyst stability. The interaction of Pt-Mo seems to play an important role. Keywords Hydrodeoxygenation Dibenzofuran Platinum Molybdenum Zirconium SBA-15 1 Introduction Intensive industrial development requires new forms of energy with minimal environmental impact. The replacement of petroleum by bio-oil for the production of fuels in the transport sector is one of the best alternatives available today because they are obtained from biomass. Through fast pyrolysis processes [1,2], the lignocellulosic biomass is transformed into liquid products known as bio-oils, as well as fuel gas and coal. However, bio-oil cannot be used directly as fuel, mainly due to its high content of water (>–30% wt) and oxygen (>40%) [3] that confers poor chemical stability and immiscibility in hydrocarbons fuels. Therefore, further processing of these bio-oils is necessary [4]. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is one of the most important processes to improve the properties of bio-oil. This is carried out under high-pressure conditions and moderate temperatures (250–500 °C) and in the presence of bi-functional catalysts [5]. The HDO process is used to decrease the oxygen content of the bio-oil. In the course of this process, oxygen atoms present in the bio-oil are eliminated mainly in the form of water, giving rise to compounds without oxygen, which are more efficient energy carriers [4]. Due to this, the yields of liquid hydrocarbons are considerably higher and, in addition, other harmful properties that are a consequence of the high oxygen content in the bio-oil are mitigated such as high viscosity, poor heating value, immiscibility with hydrocarbon fuels, thermal instability, high corrosiveness and undesirable coke formation [6,7]. To eliminate the oxygen present in the bio-oil, numerous types of supported bi-functional catalysts have been developed. The advantage of using bi-functional catalysts is that they have metal centers capable of activating hydrogen, as well as acid sites that interact with oxygen-containing molecules [8]. The bi-functionality can be implemented by adding a second metal or using a acid support. Initially, traditional catalysts in hydrodesulfurization processes (HDS) were used [9–12]. However, these catalysts have some essential disadvantages, such as rapid deactivation under HDO conditions [13,14], the need for preliminary sulfurization [15–17] and the need to employ high temperatures [18]. Therefore, over time, they were rejected in search of another type of catalysts based on transition metals [19–25] and/or noble metals [14,18,26–28], which did not need a source of sulfur and also and better yields and longer useful life. Noble metals have shown interesting results in hydrodeoxygenation reactions, being active even at low temperatures [29–31]. This provides certain advantages to the catalyst system, such as the possibility of avoiding thermal reactions that lead to operational instability, thus preventing the formation of coke and consequently the deactivation of the catalyst. Numerous studies that employ noble metals as catalysts for HDO are found in the literature [14,18,26–28,32,33]. Among all, Pt has shown high hydrogenation (HYD) capacity in the HDO reaction of dibenzofuran (DBF) [34–36]. However, the high price of noble metals cannot be forgotten and, to reduce the cost of the catalyst, total or partial replacement by new active phases is strongly recommended. The addition of a second metal has been the traditional way of reducing noble metal loading in the catalyst formulation [5,30,37], although a compromise between HDO activity and noble metal loading should be reached. Considering that bifunctional catalysts are required in HDO, metal and acid sites, the addition of a second metal can be used to generate the required bifunctionality. Thus, noble metal would activate hydrogen and the second metal would activate oxygenated groups. Among the transition metals of low cost and high reduction capacity, the most studied have been nickel, cobalt, iron, copper or molybdenum. [38–40]. Do et al. studied bimetallic catalysts, using Ni and Co as transition metals and Pt as noble metal (NiPt, CoPt) supported on alumina, which showed greater activity and selectivity than the monometallic Pt catalyst in the HDO reaction of m-cresol [40], due to the generation of additional active sites (acids) for the dehydration of alcohol and, consequently, improving selectivity towards saturated cyclic hydrocarbons. Other researchers studied catalysts based on PtMo supported on Al2O3, where the presence of molybdenum increased the selectivity towards deoxygenated products in the reaction with m-cresol with respect to the monometallic Pt catalyst [39]. The use of Mo in HDO is scarce. Y. Román and his research group studied the ability of MoO3 as a catalyst in HDO reactions carried out at atmospheric pressure [19,41,42]. They found that MoO3 was able to deoxygenate several molecules present in the bio-oil (m-cresol, phenol, guaiacol, etc.) presenting high activities and selectivities, and in addition with high tolerance to the deactivation by coke and poisoning by water, being also able to regenerate easily by means of calcination without loss of activity. S. Boullosa et al. [24] studied the HDO reaction of phenol using different molybdenum species supported on TiO2. The catalysts showed good activity with a high capacity of Mo to establish the control of the selectivity in HDO reactions of bio-oil. Based on the experimental results, it seems that Mo acts as a promoter of the active sites, affecting the catalytic activity and the selectivity influencing the type and dispersion of the active sites of the catalyst [43]. These studies suggest that molybdenum-based catalysts have unique properties that make them suitable for their use as catalysts in HDO reactions. In particular, the catalytic material is cost effective and active at moderate temperatures (200–400 °C). On the other hand, and regardless of the catalytic reaction being studied, the effectiveness of a catalyst depends to a large extent on the support used to host the active phase. Therefore, the choice of support is a key factor in the conversion and selectivity of the catalyst [44,45]. Moreover, the catalyst bifunctionality required in HDO reactions can also be added by using acidic supports. The support, in this case, plays a twofold role: in one hand it should improve active phase dispersion and in the other, it provides acid sites. Several supports have been studied in HDO reactions. The first one studied was the traditional hydrotreating catalyst support, γ-alumina, [46–49], mainly due to its large surface area, high thermal stability, ease of modifying its structure and low cost. However, its strong acidity favors coke formation, leading to catalyst deactivation. Other supports employed have been activated carbon, TiO2, ZrO2, Nb2O5, zeolites, and mesoporous materials, the later presenting better results due to their high surface area and moderate [13,18,26,50–52] or neutral [53,54] acidity, to improve active phase dispersion and avoiding catalyst deactivation by coke formation on strong acid sites. Among all of them, SBA-15 has stood out for its excellent properties, since, unlike other mesoporous supports, it is more easily synthesized in large quantities with a high constant yield. In addition, its physicochemical structure allows a high dispersion of the metal particles on the support. Among other advantages, it stands out for having surface areas of the order of 600 to 1000 m2/g, a structure with hexagonal pores interconnected each other [55,56], tunable pore size as well as the possibility of functionalization by incorporating metals, such as Al, Zr or Ti [57,58]. In this sense, the incorporation of zirconium seems to favor the activation of oxygen compounds on the surface of the support [59]. With these premises in mind, in this paper, the incorporation of bifunctionality to Pt-based catalysts for HDO reactions by using mesoporous SBA-15 support is evaluated. On one hand, it is evaluated the addition of Mo to Pt/SBA-15, and on the other the presence of Zr in the SBA-15 support, and finally the coexistence of Mo and Zr. The prepared catalysts were evaluated in the HDO reaction of DBF as a model compound of bio-oil. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents The reagents used for the synthesis of support materials were: Pluronic [Poly(ethylene glycol)-block-poly(propylene glycol)-block-poly(ethylene glycol)] (EO20PO20EO20) from Sigma-Aldrich; sulfuric acid (H2SO4) 95% from Technical VWR Prolabo Chemicals; sodium hydroxide (NaOH) from Technical VWR Prolabo Chemicals; sodium silicate solution from Sigma-Aldrich; hydrochloric acid (HCl) 37% from Technical VWR Prolabo Chemicals; tetraethyl orthosilicate 98% from Sigma-Aldrich; zirconyl chloride octahydrate (ZrOCl2.8 H2O) 98% from Sigma-Aldrich. The precursor salts employed for catalysts preparation were ammonium tetracloroplatinate(II) ((NH4)2PtCl4) from Sigma Aldrich and ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6 Mo7 O24.24 H2O) from Fluka. 2.2 Synthesis of supports SBA-15 and SBA-15 doped with zirconium were used as catalyst supports. The mesoporous silicas were prepared by following the procedure described by Cazalilla et al for SBA-15 and K. Szczodrowski et al. [58] for ZrSBA-15 (Si/Zr = 10). To this end, in the synthesis of SBA-15 support, 25 g of pluronic were added to 1 L of H2SO4 and stirred until pluronic was completely dissolved. After 1 g of NaOH was dissolved, 986 mL of an aqueous solution of sodium silicate (6.7 vol%) were added dropwise and stirred for five days. After that, it was filtered and washed with deionized water, dried at 60 °C for 24 h and then calcined at 550 °C for 6 h. In the case of Zr-SBA-15, 10 g of pluronic were dissolved in water and stirred until pluronic was completely dissolved. Then, 293 g of 2 M aqueous solution of HCl and 3.3 g of Zr precursor were added and stirred for 15 min prior to the addition of 22.3 mL of TEOS. The final suspension was stirred for two days and after that, it was filtered, washed with deionized water, dried at 60 °C for 24 h and then calcined at 550 °C for 6 h. The samples were denoted as SBA and ZrSBA. 2.3 Catalyst materials The supports synthesized were impregnated with an aqueous solution containing the proper concentration of precursor salts of platinum (ammonium tetracloroplatinate(II) (NH4)2PtCl4 from Sigma Aldrich) and molybdenum (ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate (NH4)6 Mo7 O24.24 H2O from Fluka, Sigma Aldrich). Then, the materials were dried at 60 °C for 24 h and finally calcined at 550 °C for 6 h, using a heating ramp of 10 °C min−1. The obtained catalysts were denoted as Pt/SBA, Pt/ZrSBA, PtMo/SBA and PtMo/ZrSBA. Bimetallic samples contained a total metallic loading of 2 wt% and Pt/Mo molar ratio of 1. Monometallic ones presented a metallic loading equal to 1 wt%. 2.4 Catalytic activity The prepared catalysts were evaluated in the HDO reaction employing dibenzofuran (DBF) as a model molecule of bio-oil. The hydrotreating reaction was performed in a high-pressure fixed-bed continuous-flow stainless steel catalytic reactor with an interior placed thermocouple in direct contact with the catalytic bed. The liquid O-containing feed was supplied with a Gilson 307SC piston pump (model 10SC). For the activity tests, 0.25 g of fresh catalysts (particle size 0.85–1.00 mm) were used, diluted with SiC to 3 cm3. The reactions were carried out at 275 °C under 3.0 MPa of H2; the H2 flow being of 30 mL min―1 and the organic feed flow of 0.18 mL min―1 supplied with a Gilson 307SC piston pump (LHSV = 3.6 h―1, GHSV = 7200 Ncc/gcath, H2 contact time = 6 s, H2/DBF = 69.1). The catalysts were not pretreated before the tests. The activity is described in terms of the HDO conversion according to Eq. (1): (1) X H D O = n 0 h - ∑ n o x i n 0 h · 100 where n0h is the initial amount of DBF and noxi are the amounts of oxygenated compounds. The evolution of the reaction was studied by collecting liquid samples each 60 min, which were kept in sealed vials and subsequently analyzed in a Shimadzu GC-14B gas chromatograph equipped with a TBR-14 capillary column. 2.5 Characterization of samples The characterization was carried out in the as-prepared samples without any pretreatment. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns of samples were collected on a PAN analytical X'Pert Pro automated diffractometer. Powder patterns were recorded at low angle between 1 and 10° in 2θ, and at high angle between 10 and 80° in 2θ, with a step size of 0.0167° (2θ) and an equivalent counting time of ∼60 s/step, in Bragg-Brentano reflection configuration by using a Ge (111) primary monochromator, using monochromatic Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5406 Å) and an X´Celerator detector. BET specific surface areas were obtained from nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms at ―196 °C on a Micrometric ASAP 2020 apparatus with all samples outgassed at 200 °C for 10 h prior to analysis. The acidity of pure supports and prepared catalysts was determined by temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) measurements. To that end, 80 mg of solid were put in a quartz sample holder through which a flow of He was passed while the temperature was risen from room temperature to 550 °C; after having left it cool to 100 °C, an ammonia flow was passed for 5 min. Once the physisorbed ammonia was removed at the same temperature by flushing with He (35 mL·min―1), the NH3-TPD experiment was carried out rising the temperature up to 800 °C at a constant heating rate of 10 °C min―1 under the same He flow. The effluent composition was determined using a TCD detector. The reducibility of the samples was studied by temperature-programmed reduction in flowing H2 (TPR-H2); each sample was cleaned in a flow of He (35 mL·min−1) at 100 °C for half an hour; after cooling the furnace to 45 °C, samples were then heated in H2 flow (45 mL·min−1) to 700 °C using a heating ramp of 10 °C min−1. The measurement was recorded on a Shimadzu GC-14b chromatograph. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were performed on a Physical Electronics PHI 5701 spectrometer. Non-monochromatic Mg-Kα radiation (300 W, 15 kV, 1253.6 eV) and a multi-channel detector were employed. Samples were analyzed in a constant pass energy mode at 29.35 eV. Charge referencing was measured against Si 2p at 103.4 eV. Solid-state NMR spectra were carried out on a BRUKER High Definition Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectrometer model AVIIIHD 600 with a magnetic field of 14.09 T. 29Si analysis was performed using the Hpdec technique, at a rotation speed of 15 kHz and cw decoupling sequence. Measurements were carried out on a 2.5 mm Triple Resonance DVT Probe and double wideband range. The spectra were registered with 4200 scans. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic test The catalytic activity of Pt(Mo)/SBA(Zr) catalysts was investigated in a fixed-bed reactor at 3 MPa and 275 °C. Dibenzofuran (DBF) was chosen as a model molecule. Fig. 1 a depicts the evolution of HDO conversion versus time on stream, where it is clearly observed how the presence of Mo improves the catalytic response and stabilizes the catalyst. The corresponding monometallic Mo sample was also tested but did not present catalytic activity. A comparison of the conversion values, both total and HDO ones, after 6 h on stream is represented in Fig. 1b. According to the results presented in Fig. 1b, significant differences were observed among the four samples, and important conclusions about the role of Zr or Mo on these systems can be extracted. Thus, total conversion and HDO conversion increased after the incorporation of Mo. Instead, Zr addition worsened the catalytic behavior of pure SBA supported catalysts. Considering Pt/SBA catalyst the values of total and HDO conversion were different, that is, this catalyst converted DBF molecules into both O-free and O-containing compounds, being the yield to O-free compounds lower than 20%. After the addition of Mo, the catalytic response sharply increased, moreover the attained values of total and HDO conversion were close and as high as 85–87%. The use of ZrSBA instead of SBA was detrimental to these systems in terms of conversion. The corresponding catalyst, Pt/ZrSBA, converted a very low amount of DBF molecules, close to 5%, both conversion values were similar. However, again, the addition of Mo was very positive and the same behavior than for SBA sample was observed, its presence increased the conversion considerably with respect to the sample without Mo. The conversion reached values close to 62–70%. Therefore, considering these conversion values, it can be stated that the conversion followed the trend: PtMo/SBA > PtMo/ZrSBA > Pt/SBA and Pt/ZrSBA. The addition of Mo presented a significant improvement of the catalytic activity in HDO reaction, as had already been observed in previous works [35,36], but Zr presence was not so relevant, even worsened the catalytic behavior. A possible cause of deactivation of the catalysts is the formation of coke deposits on their surface. Table 1 shows the percentage of carbon deposited in the catalysts aftreaction. The addition of Mo decreased the percentage of carbon deposited on the surface of the catalysts, especially in the PtMo/SBA sample, which is consistent with the catalytic results obtained by the bimetallic catalysts that were much more stable than their monometallic counterparts. In the monometallic catalysts, the incorporation of Zr to SBA decreases the amount of carbon deposited, although in this case, the carbon percentage does not correlate with the catalytic activity data. And for bimetallic catalysts, the addition of Zr results in a higher percentage of carbon deposits in the PtMo/ZrSBA, that could explain the lower activity of Zr based samples. Regarding the distribution of products obtained, this varied with the level of conversion, that is, they depended on the catalytic activity. The main reaction products detected were: cyclohexane (CH), dodecahydrodibenzofuran (DHDBF), tetrahydrodibenzofuran (THDBF), 2-cyclohexylphenol (2-CHP), cyclopentylcyclohexane (C-PE-CH) and cyclopentylmethylcyclohexane (C-PE-ME-CH). Fig. 2 groups the selectivity data obtained by the supported catalysts. The main deoxygenated products obtained were CH, C-PE-CH, C-PE-ME-CH and as oxygenated intermediates DHDBF, THDBF and 2-CHP. Scheme 1 includes the mechanisms of HDO of DBF. Considering the product distribution, the absence of Mo and Zr in the Pt/SBA catalyst gave rise to the worst distribution of O-free products, being this catalyst the one that obtained the highest percentage of oxygenated intermediates. As deoxygenated compounds, it was obtained mainly C-PE-CH (19%) and C-PE-ME-CH (24%). However, when Zr was incorporated into the support (Pt/ZrSBA), the catalytic response improved in terms of selectivity, achieving a significant reduction in the percentage of oxygenated intermediates, obtaining only 13.7% of THDBF and as deoxygenated compounds, it obtained mainly CH and in a lesser extent C-PE-ME-CH. The best distribution of HDO products was obtained by incorporating Mo into the catalyst formulation although the distribution depended on the presence or absence of Zr. Thus, the catalyst PtMo/SBA was the one that achieved the highest percentage of deoxygenated products, mainly C-PE-ME-CH and C-PE-CH. As oxygenated intermediates insignificant amounts were obtained, lower than 5%. Finally, when Mo was incorporated into the Pt/ZrSBA catalyst, the selectivity to O-free products changed compared to the monometallic one. C-PE-ME-CH (41.7%), CH (21.1%) and C-PE-CH (17.5%) were the main ones. In this case, the selectivity to oxygenated intermediates was close to 4%. These data point to the hydrogenation route as the preferred one, where ring saturation occurs. Zr and Mo addition improved the yield of HDO reaction improving the hydrogenolysis capability of the resultant catalyst. Incorporation of Mo mainly increased the selectivity of C-PE-ME-CH, and C-PE-CH in smaller measure, not only obtaining products from hydrogenation reactions. The incorporation of Zr in the catalyst formulation, improved the formation of CH, suggesting that the increase of acidity favors the breakage of the double ring. These data are in accordance with the requirement of bifunctional catalysts for HDO reaction. Thus, Pt/SBA sample requires the presence of acid sites to activate oxygenated groups to improve the yield to O-free products. Once Zr and/or Mo are present in the catalyst formulation, the HDO conversion improves and therefore suggesting that hydrogen activation occurs on Pt sites and C-O cleavage takes place on acidic sites. 3.2 Characterization results Fig. 3 shows the corresponding X-ray diffractograms at low angles of each synthesized support. The striking similarity in low angle XRD patterns suggests that hexagonal ordering was retained in all the cases. An intense peak was observed for the supports SBA and Zr/SBA that is related to the hexagonal ordering of the silica [60]. In both cases, after active phase deposition, the diffraction peak was shifted to higher values, indicative of the incorporation of the active phase inside the mesoporous structure. The fact that this peak was maintained after the impregnation with metals demonstrates that the structure of SBA-15 material was not destroyed. At high angle (Fig. 4 ), it was seen a broad hump in the 20–30º 2 theta region, associated to the amorphous nature of these mesoporous materials. Moreover, it was observed in all cases, with the exception of ZrSBA support, the presence of two diffraction peaks at 16.4 and 42.8º which are correlated to some silica aggregates formed during the synthesis and catalyst preparation. Moreover, three diffraction main peaks appeared at 39.8, 46.3 and 67.7° which were assigned to Pt0 (PDF 01-087-0640). The three peaks corresponded to the facets (111), (200) and (220) [61] of Pt. It was not observed reflection peaks for Mo species ascribed to the low charge of this metal and probably presenting a high dispersion on the supports. An estimation of the crystal particle size was carried out by using Scherrer equation. Table 2 includes these values. The crystalline particle sizes ranged between 8.3 nm and 20.0 nm and depended on the support employed and the catalyst composition. In this sense, lower particle size was obtained on SBA support and in the absence of Mo and Zr. The particle size followed the trend: Pt/SBA < Pt/ZrSBA < PtMo/SBA < PtMo/ZrSBA. The textural characteristics of the synthesized supports were examined by adsorption-desorption from N2 at -196 °C. The adsorption-desorption isotherm of N2 and the corresponding pore size distribution are shown in Figs. 5 and 6 . The corresponding textural properties in terms of surface areas, pore volume and pore width of the bare supports are included in Table 1. The surface area obtained was quite high, above 600 m2 g−1 for both supports. The isotherms obtained were of type IV according to IUPAC classification [62], and the hysteresis cycle of H2 type, characteristic of ordered mesoporous materials, in which percolation occurs due to the interconnection in the pore network. The initial increase in adsorption volume at low pressures is due to the monolayer adsorption in micro and mesopores. Moreover, both supports presented a narrow hysteresis loop in the P/P0 region between 0.30 and 0.99 in ZrSBA and between 0.42 and 0.99 in SBA, due to capillary condensation inside mesopores. The most important difference between both samples is the pore size. Thus, SBA sample presented pores of higher size (4.4 nm) than ZrSBA (2.9 nm) that can be played an important role to host metallic phases. In fact, the obtained crystalline particle sizes were higher in the case of ZrSBA support that could be related to its lower pore size. The incorporation of Pt and PtMo to the SBA support (Fig. 5A) resulted in a decrease in the volume of N2 adsorbed compared to the pure support throughout the range of relative pressures studied. The results (Table 2) show a considerable decrease in the BET surface area, which could be attributed to the blocking of the pores by deposition, inside the pores, of Pt and PtMo particles. The inclusion of particles inside the channels is evidenced by the diffraction peak at low angles that are slightly shifted to higher values in the presence of Pt and Mo. Moreover, the pore size distribution was also shifted to lower values after metal incorporation, corroborating this fact. So that the metallic particles could be hosted inside the pores, resulting in a decrease in the volume of the pore observed in both catalysts compared to the pure support. A similar behavior was observed when the metal phases (Pt and Mo) were incorporated to ZrSBA support (Fig. 6). Again, the pore volume pore size decreased, indicating the location of metallic particles inside the channels. Since the acidity of the catalysts is an important factor that influences their activity in the hydrodeoxygenation reaction of bio-oil, the acidic properties of the samples were analyzed by temperature programmed desorption of NH3. Table 3 shows the amount of desorbed NH3 (μmol NH3 g−1) based catalysts supported of Pt and PtMo and the fresh SBA and ZrSBA supports. From the corresponding signals, significant differences were observed depending on the support employed. Considering the behavior observed by these families of compounds the amount of ammonia desorbed was quantified considering three main zones as indicated in Table 3. For SBA support the main ammonia desorption band took place at low temperature (<250 °C) although this sample also desorbed a small amount at medium temperatures. After Pt and PtMo addition, the desorption band at low temperatures decreased in intensity meanwhile, the profile desorption at medium temperatures (250–550 °C) changed. This is indicative of the preferential location of metallic phases on the acid sites of the support, probably ascribed to OH sites (See RMN results below), and the creation of new ones of stronger acidity and associated to metallic phases. PtMo/SBA sample evidenced the acidity created by the presence of Mo if compared to Pt/SBA sample, thus the ammonia desorbed between 300–550 °C was higher. So, from these data, it was observed that the acidity of SBA samples was mainly of weak nature (see desorption between 100–300 °C) and the incorporation of Mo, mainly, increased the presence of medium strength acid sites. In this family, the normalized acidity decreased after Pt addition but increased due to the effect of Mo in the case of bimetallic samples. Considering ZrSBA family, the ammonia desorption profile of ZrSBA support was totally different from that presented by SBA, as expected. The main desorption peak was shifted to higher temperatures, 160 °C for SBA to 180 °C for ZrSBA, pointing to a stronger acidity in the later. In this case, the contributions of each zone were more evident and this family presented a great proportion of both low and medium strength acid sites. The incorporation of Pt, as in the case of SBA, provoked a decrease of the main band at low temperatures (centered at ca. 180 °C) and a broadened of the signal, again indicating the location of Pt on the acid sites of the support and the creation of new ones. Moreover, it was also observed a slight increase in the total amount desorbed in Zone 2. In the case of PtMo/ZrSBA sample, the addition of Mo increased the amount of ammonia desorbed in Zones I and II and therefore the amount of weak and medium acid sites compared to that of Pt/ZrSBA sample. The development of acid sites in molybdenum-containing catalysts is usually related to the presence of coordinated Mo6+ species on the surface (acid-Lewis sites) [63], although in the case of PtMo bimetallic systems, the increase in acidity after Mo incorporation is related to the formation of new Bronsted acid sites [64]. NMR results will support this idea. In order to dwell into the interaction of metals (Pt and Mo) with the SBA structures as well as to evaluate OH- sites present, 29Si solid-state NMR analyses were carried out. Thus, possible changes in the coordination state of Si after Pt and Mo incorporation (Fig. 7 ) can be elucidated. 29Si NMR spectra were recorded for bare supports (SBA and ZrSBA) and Pt and PtMo containing samples. Fig. 7 depicts the corresponding spectra. In all cases, two main signals located at −111 and −101 ppm were noticeable, which is reported to be due to Si(OSi)x(OH)4-x units, where x = 3 (Q3) and x = 4 (Q4), respectively [65]. The small contribution at -91 ppm could be assigned to Si(OSi)2(OH)2 species (Q2) [66]. By comparing all the spectra, it was observed that Q4 sites were those mainly affected by metallic deposition on the support. While the addition of only Pt shifted Q3 signals to higher values, the presence of both Pt and Mo changed the distribution of Q3-Q4 sites. Q3 sites seem to be those mainly presented by metallic deposition. A greater proportion of OH sites, responsible for Bronsted acidity, were present after active phase deposition, corroborating NH3-TPD results. Moreover, Q2 sites were hardly affected. The reducibility of the species present was evaluated from H2-TPR experiments. The corresponding reduction proﬁles are depicted in Fig. 8 . In the case of the monometallic Pt/SBA catalyst, it showed a weak and broad band centered at ca. 130 °C, as well as one at higher temperature whose maximum is located at 365 °C. So it implies the presence of Pt particles presenting different reducibility probably associated with different particle size: higher particles highly reducible, and smaller ones strongly interacting with the support whose reduction is much more difficult. The presence of Mo altered the reduction profile. Thus, the reduction band at low temperature disappeared and that at higher temperature was much more important with three distinguishable contributions: that at 365 °C associated to Pt and two new ones at 415 and 480 °C due to Mo reduction. The literature data point that this temperature range of reduction of molybdenum species is characteristic of molybdenum oxide supported on silica [67]. So, it can be stated here that Mo presence improves the reducibility of Pt species. In the case of the samples supported on ZrSBA, the reduction profiles were different. Pt/ZrSBA sample showed a broad band between 300 and 600 °C, indicating that this sample did not present highly reducible Pt oxide particles as in the case of Pt/SBA sample and associated to the stronger interaction of Pt with the acidic support. The addition of Mo shifted the reduction profile to lower temperatures, but due to the reduction of Pt and Mo on this sample is evolved in the same curve it was not possible to distinguish if Pt reduction was improved. However, it PtMo/ZrSBA is compared to PtMo/SBA, the reduction of Mo occurred at a lower temperature in the former indicating better reducibility of Mo on ZrSBA. This fact is explained considering the activation of hydrogen on the metallic particles and ulterior spillover on the support or in this case to Mo species [68]. From these profiles, it is expected that the interaction Pt-Mo and therefore the relative location on the support will be different on each sample. The surface chemical composition of the fresh catalysts was evaluated by XPS. The Si 2p binding energies were very similar (103.4 eV) for the four studied samples and were attributed to the O-SiO of SiO2 phase [69]. The Zr 3d signal was not affected by the incorporation of Mo. Considering the Mo 3d signal (Fig. 9 ), in both catalysts two contributions due to the spin-orbit doublet of Mo 3d were observed, the binding energy of the Mo 3d 5/2 component located at 232.8 eV for the PtMo/SBA sample and 232.7 eV for the PtMo/ZrSBA sample. These values are in agreement with those reported for MoO3 [19,70]. The Pt 4f core level spectra of catalysts showed two doublets in all cases, as seen in Fig. 9. The Pt 4f 7/2 component corresponding to the catalysts without Mo was located at 70.7 eV and is assigned to Pt0, and the second component was located at 71.7 eV in the Pt/SBA-15 and at 71.9 eV in the Pt/ZrSBA catalysts, characteristic of Pt2+ corresponding to PtO [71]. The presence of Mo in the catalysts increased the binding energy of the first doublet with respect to the catalysts without Mo, 71.2 eV for PtMo/SBA and 71.1 eV for PtMo/ZrSBA. The same increase in the binding energy occurred with the second doublet in the samples with Zr. PtMo/SBA catalyst presented this doublet slightly shifted to higher binding energies, and the proportion of this species associated to platinum oxide is much lower than in the other cases, that is, this catalyst possesses the greater proportion of reduced platinum. In general, Pt signal shifted to higher binding energy under the presence of Mo and Zr. These results are probably due to the interaction of Pt with Mo and also with the support when Zr is present. As a consequence of Pt and Mo interaction, the reducibility of Pt was improved, as evidenced by the contribution of each species (Table 4 ) and also from H2-TPR results. The interaction of Pt with ZrSBA support worsened the reducibility, also evidenced from H2-TPR results. The surface atomic ratios, summarized in Table 5 , indicated that metal surface exposure strongly depended on both Mo and Zr presence. Considering Mo effect, Pt/Si and Pt/(Si + Zr) atomic ratios increased and the same effect provoked the presence of Zr on the mesoporous structure, an improvement of the Pt surface exposure, and therefore Pt dispersion. Instead, Mo exposure decreased under the presence of Zr. Thus the addition of bifunctionality improved the Pt exposure on the surface, but the presence of acid sites on the support was detrimental for Mo exposure. These data suggest that Mo should be interacting with the acid sites of the support (Zr sites) and pt should be preferentially located on Mo particles and therefore hindering Mo detection by the X-ray beam. This catalyst configuration explains the shift of the reduction profile to lower temperature in the PtMo/ZrSBA sample compared to PtMo/SBA one. The activation of H2 on Pt metallic sites are spilled to Mo ones beneath Pt. Instead, in the case of PtMo/SBA the fact that Mo surface exposure was much higher (seven times higher), a great proportion of Mo is not covered by platinum. Moreover, as it was observed that Pt reducibility was improved in both cases after Mo addition, as evidenced by XPS results and H2-TPR, but in a better way for PtMo/SBA, it is expected in this sample the metallic phases are close to modify Pt reducibility and presenting high dispersion due to the high metal surface exposure observed for this catalyst. 4 Conclusions The different catalytic behavior of the catalysts prepared evidenced the importance of the bifunctionality in HDO. Conversion values indicated that both Mo and acid sites on the support improved the hydrogenolysis capability of the resultant catalyst since HDO and total conversion values were closer than in the case of Pt/SBA sample. Differences in the acidity, active phase dispersion/surface exposure, reducibility and interaction between the metal components explain the catalytic results. In general, the addition of Mo was more relevant than the use of acidic support, although in both cases the acidity (mainly Bronsted type) was improved, the reducibility of Pt was better and the amount of carbon deposited was lower by incorporating Mo. Moreover, in the absence of stronger acid sites, molybdenum surface exposure is higher and should play an important role in the resultant activity of the HDO catalyst. PtMo/SBA catalyst was that presenting better results due to moderate acidity, high reducibility, and high metal surface exposure. coredata.dc:description: Mesoporous silica SBA-15 and ZrSBA-15 (Si/Zr = 10) were prepared and used as supports of platinum and molybdenum based catalysts to be tested in the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) reaction of dibenzofuran (DBF) as a model compound present in biomass derived bio-oil, at 3 MPa and 275 °C. It is evaluated the bifunctionality of Pt based catalysts by adding Mo to the catalyst formulation or by increasing the acidity of the material support employed. The catalysts showed significant differences in HDO activity as well as selectivity towards O-free products. The incorporation of Mo positively affected the DBF conversion and selectivity, obtaining better results than monometallic catalysts. In contrast, the presence of Zr in the support sharply decreased the conversion of the monometallic Pt sample and also of the bimetallic PtMo one, although in a lesser extent. Considering characterization results, the activity was explained in terms of acidity, reducibility, surface metal exposure and interaction between the phases present. PtMo/SBA-15 sample presented better catalytic results due to an intermediate acidity, better reducibility and greater Pt + Mo surface exposure. Moreover, the presence of Mo decreases the amount of carbon on the surface, improving the catalyst stability. The interaction of Pt-Mo seems to play an important role.
coredata.dc:title: Study of bifunctionality of Pt/SBA-15 catalysts for HDO of Dibenzofuran reaction: Addition of Mo or use of an acidic support
